Australia's gambling regulation is managed by a combination of federal and state/territory regulatory bodies. These regulators oversee various aspects of gambling activities, ensuring compliance with laws and protecting consumers. The division of responsibilities between federal and state/territory bodies allows for comprehensive oversight and enforcement across the nation.

== Federal Regulatory Bodies ==

The federal government of Australia has several agencies responsible for different aspects of gambling regulation, particularly focusing on online gambling, anti-money laundering, consumer protection, and policy development.

== State and Territory Regulatory Bodies ==

Each state and territory in Australia has its own regulatory body that manages gambling activities within its jurisdiction. These bodies are responsible for licensing, compliance, and enforcement of local gambling laws.

== Role of Each Regulator ==

Each regulator has specific roles, including issuing licenses, monitoring compliance, handling consumer complaints, and enforcing gambling laws. They also provide guidance and support to operators and consumers.

== How to Contact Regulators ==

Regulators can be contacted through their official websites, where they provide resources and contact information for inquiries and complaints. Each regulator has specific procedures for handling complaints and enforcement actions.

== Complaints and Enforcement Processes ==

Complaints about gambling operators can be lodged with the relevant state or territory regulator. These bodies have the authority to investigate and enforce compliance with gambling laws. Federal regulators, such as ACMA and AUSTRAC, handle issues related to online gambling and financial compliance.
